Anthony Atala is Professor and Chair in the Department of Urology and Director of the Institute for Regenerative Medicine at Wake Forest University School of Medicine in Winston-Salem, North Carolina.
He joins us today by phone from his office.
Welcome to the program.
Thank you.
Tell us about these - are they true stem cells?
Well, that is exactly the question we asked ourselves about seven years ago.
You know, could we find a population of true stem cells in the amniotic fluid and the placenta.
Of course, the amniotic fluid being the fluid that surrounds the developing baby while it's being carried in the mother's womb.
And their answer was?

And the answer was indeed, there was a true stem-cell population that could be found both in the amniotic fluid as well as the placenta, which is the tissue, of course, that surrounds the baby and the fluid during development.
Are these embryonic stem cells that you found?
They are not embryonic stem cells, in fact.
They're a class of its own.
They're neither embryonic nor adult, but they have properties of both.
Such as?
Well for example, they're closer to human embryonic stem cells, which makes sense because developmentally, they're closer to that timeline.
But like human embryonic stem cells, the cells are able to grow very rapidly.
They double in number every 36 hours, which is one of the advantages, of course, of human embryonic stem cells.
We also found markers consistent with human embryonic stem cells, but to our surprise, after we started growing these cells, we also found markers consistent with adult stem cells.
In addition, human embryonic stem cells have the telomerase gene, which of course is the fountain-of-youth gene, if you will, and that is what allows these cells to keep growing in large quantities.

And it turned out that these cells, also like human embryonic stem cells, were able to preserve their length of the telomere, which is the little end protein that gets preserved every time the cell divides so that the cell can keep dividing and dividing without giving up after a period of time.

I'm sorry?

So we knew that there were all these cells, which were present, like bone cells and cartilage and muscle cells, in the amniotic fluid.
